person_469.name: Ovid
person_469.description: Roman poet who lived during the reign of Augustus.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_267.name: Abraham GottlobWerner
person_267.description: German geologist who proposed the theory of Neptunism and who also proposed the chronological sequence found in stratified rocks.

person_520.name: Jean-AndréDeluc
person_520.description: Swiss-born geologist, natural philosopher and meteorologist who spent much of his time working in England. FRSL.

person_1005.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
person_1005.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

person_519.name: WilliamWhiston
person_519.description: English (unorthodox) theologian, historian, natural philosopher, and mathematician. A leading figure in promoting the ideas of Isaac Newton whom he succeeded as Lucasian Professor.

person_595.name: Charles FrancisGreville
person_595.description: A British antiquarian, collector and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1774 to 1790. FRSL.

person_634.name: Jacques Louis deBournon
person_634.description: French born mineralogist who lived and worked in London. An Annual Subscribed to the Royal Institution, he was founder member of the Geological Society. FRSL.

person_226.name: ThomasThomson
person_226.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

person_599.name: Rene JustHauy
person_599.description: Hauy was a French priest and mineralogist. He helped to establish the metric system.

person_307.name: René JustHaüy
person_307.description: French priest, crystallographer and mineralogist who wrote the five volume Traité de minéralogie (1801). ForMemRSL.

person_301.name: RobertJameson
person_301.description: Scottish geologist and Regius Professor of Natural History at the University of Edinburgh. FRSL.

person_377.name: JohnMayow
person_377.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

person_271.name: Alexander vonHumboldt
person_271.description: German geographer, naturalist and explorer. ForMemRSL.

person_300.name: Déodat Gratet deDolomieu
person_300.description: French geologist. The rock, and region of the Alps, dolomite was named after him.

person_368.name: Horace Bénédict deSaussure
person_368.description: Genevan geologist, meteorologist, physicist, mountaineer and Alpine expolorer. Often referred to as the founder of Alpinism and modern meteorology.

person_162.name: JohnPlayfair
person_162.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

person_125.name: JamesHutton
person_125.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

person_164.name: JamesHall
person_164.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

place_1395.name: Pacific Ocean
place_1395.description: The largest and deepest of Earth's five oceans.

place_991.name: Freiberg
place_991.description: A university and former mining town in Saxony, Germany

place_021.name: Cornwall
place_021.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

place_044.name: Wicklow
place_044.description: County Wicklow is a county in Ireland on the east coast, south of Dublin.

place_047.name: Donegal
place_047.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_990.name: Siberia
place_990.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

place_053.name: Sligo
place_053.description: The town of Sligo, in the north of Ireland, straddles the Garavogue River where it meets Sligo Bay.

place_993.name: Mayo
place_993.description: A county in the west of Ireland

place_286.name: Leicestershire
place_286.description: A county in the East Midlands of England.

place_485.name: Mountsorrel
place_485.description: Mountsorrel is a village in Leicestershire bordering the Charnwood Forest, an upland area with isolated outcrops of ancient Precambrian igneous rocks.

place_507.name: Charnwood Forest
place_507.description: The Charnwood Forest is a upland area in Leicestershire, the highest point being 278m. The geology is remarkable as Precambrian igneous rocks, some of the oldest rocks on earth, are seen as isolated outcrops, as in Davy's sketch.

place_302.name: Nether Stowey
place_302.description: A village in Somerset, home of the tanner Thomas Poole and formerly Samuel Taylor Coleridge.
